sect1.title: General interface decription
sect1.para: VLC has several interfaces: a cross-platform interface, for Windows and GNU/Linux, called wxwindows, a MacOS X native interface and a skinnable interface for Windows and GNU/Linux.

sect2.title: Windows and GNU/Linux
sect2.para: This is the default interface on Windows and GNU/Linux (the screenshot is done on GNU/Linux, but it would look quite the same on Windows.
This interface also features an Extended GUI which contains many additional features. To have it appear or disappear, go to the Settings menu and click Extended GUI.

sect1.title: Using the playlist
sect1.para: VLC can of course play several files, using its playlist system. To access the playlist, click on the Playlist button of the main interface (see ).
Each time you use the Open dialog box, the stream you select is appended at the end of the playlist and started.
The playlist window shows all the streams in the playlist. Double-click one to have it played.
The Manage menu allows you to append an item at the end of the playlist (but its playback won't start immediately), to save the playlist as a M3U or PLS file, or to import a playlist file.
The Sort allows you to sort the playlist according to several criteria, or to shuffle it.
The toolbar contains three playlist mode buttons to enable random mode, repeat of all the playlist and repeat of one item of the playlist.
You also have a search tool. Enter a search string and hit search. The next item to match the string will be hilighted. Keep hitting Search to cycle between all matching items.
The Up and Down buttons at the bottom of the playlist window allow you to move an item. Select an item and use these buttons to move it.

sect1.title: Using subtitles
sect1.para: VLC supports many kinds of subtitles.

Subtitles are disabled by default. To enable them, go to the Video menu, and to Subtitles track. All available subtitles tracks will be listed. Select one to get the subtitles. Depending on the media, a description (langage, for example) might be available for the track.

sect2.para: DVD and SVCD subtitles are merely images, so you won't be able to change anything for them. OGM and Matroska subtitles are rendered text, so you will be able to change several options.

Text rendering options can be changed in the Preferences. In the Modules section, text renderer subsection, open the freetype page. You can then set the font and its size. For the font, you have to select a font file. Under Windows, they can be found in C:\Windows\Fonts. Under MacOS X, they are in /System/Library/Fonts . Size can be set either relatively or as a number of pixels.
You need to restart your stream for the font modifications to take effect.

sect2.title: Subtitles files
sect2.para: While modern file formats like Matroska or OGM can handle subtitles directly, older formats like AVI can't. Therefore, a number of subtitles files formats have been created. You need two files: the video file and the subtitles files that only contains the text of the subtitles and timestamps.
VLC can handle these types of subtitles files:

listitem.para: Vobsub (this one is quite special: it is not made from text but from images, which means that you can't change the fonts)

sect2.para: To open a subtitles file, use the Advanced Open dialog box (Menu File, Open file). Select your file by clicking on the Browse button. Then, check the Subtitle options checkbox and click on the Settings button.

textobject.para: Select a subtitles file under Windows or Linux

caption.para: Select a subtitles file under Windows or Linux

sect2.para: You can then select the subtitles file by clicking the Browse button. You can also set a few options like encoding, alignment and size. The delay option allows you to delay the subtitles against the video if they are not in sync. If they are not at the same speed, you might also want to adjust the subtitles framerate.
Encoding, alignment and size won't have any effect for vobsub subtitles.
Font can be changed as explained in the previous section.

sect1.title: Video and audio filters
sect1.para: VLC includes a system of filters that allow you to modify th e audio and video.

sect3.title: Equalizer
sect3.para: VLC features a 10-band graphical equalizer. You can show it by activating the advanced GUI on wxWindows or by clicking the Equalizer button on the MacOS X interface.
Presets are available in the Audio menu in wxWindows, or in the Equalizer window in the MacOS X interface
